awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GP-IMPACT: A Geopathway Utilizing High-Tech Geoscience Experiences for Recruitment and Retention -- A Collaboration between PBSC and FAU
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
This project aims to ameliorate the current and increasing severe shortage of geoscientists in the U.S. workforce. The goal is to institutionalize a transformative model to effect a long-term, sustained increase in recruitment and retention of students from Palm Beach State College (PBSC), a two-year college (2YC), particularly more women and underrepresented minorities (URMs), into geoscience programs at Florida Atlantic University (FAU), a four-year (4yr) institution in South Florida. The proposed activities of this model, such as embedding workforce readiness components into the science curriculum at FAU and PBSC, developing and implementing Exploring Geopaths Summer Institute (EGSI) and Undergraduate Geopaths Research Experiences (UGRE), which will both expose and train more students in cutting-edge geoscience technologies, support and align with NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution, and Future of Work Big Ideas. PIs anticipate a sustained increase in graduation rates of skilled geoscientists who will enter the workforce ready and pursue employment opportunities in much needed sectors such as: energy, oil and gas, environmental services, mining, research institutes, and federal, state or local governments. Through this project PIs also intend to position PBSC and FAU students and faculty in line with NSF's INCLUDES Big Idea that "aspires to transform education and career pathways to help broaden participation in science and engineering".

Part 2
This project aims to ameliorate the current and increasing severe shortage of geoscientists in the U.S. workforce. Our goal is to institutionalize a transformative model to effect a long-term, sustained increase in recruitment and retention of students from Palm Beach State College (PBSC), a two-year college (2YC), particularly more women and underrepresented minorities (URMs), into geoscience programs at Florida Atlantic University (FAU), a four-year (4yr) institution in South Florida. By targeting the diverse student population at PBSC, the project will significantly increase the enrollment, and the number of females and URMs in geoscience programs at FAU. As part of the transformative model PIs will implement: (1) Growing the transfer student pipeline and increasing student diversity by recruiting geoscience majors from PBSC, revising and strengthening the transfer articulation agreement (Link Program), implementing geoscience-specific 2+2 transfer flight plans, developing a cross-institutional collaborative advising protocol framework, and initiating and embedding career readiness components directly into the geosciences courses taken by PBSC students prior to transferring to FAU. (2) Developing a new Exploring Geopaths Summer Institute (EGSI), with authentic experiences utilizing a rich spectrum of geoscience high-tech and field methods, designed to attract, and recruit PBSC students. (3) Developing a new Undergraduate Geopaths Research Experiences (UGRE), designed to motivate and retain transfer students early in their matriculation into geoscience degree programs at FAU. (4) Enhancing the departmental culture with faculty and peer mentors to make it a more welcoming, and supportive environment for students. PIs anticipate the outcomes will position this model as one that can be easily adopted by other institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The GEOPAths teams at Florida Atlantic University(FAU) (4-year) and Palm Beach State College (PBSC) (2-year) worked collaboratively to grow student awareness of  geoscience as a rigorous STEM discipline with a rewarding career path, and to increase the recruitment and retention of students in FAU geoscience degree programs. The outcomes from this project include:

1. FAU-PBSC Transfer Articulation Agreement.  The teams have established a geoscience specific agreement and related flight plans, which facilitates a transfer pathway for PBSC Associate of Arts (AA, 2-year) students to undergraduate degree programs leading to a B.A or B.S. in Geosciences at FAU. More information can be found at:  https://www.palmbeachstate.edu/transfer/as-degree-transfer-agreements.aspx

2. FAU Geoscience Career Booklet. A geoscience career booklet has been compiled to showcase exciting geoscience careers and promote career readiness to potential students. It is a 10-page document that details the rewarding career opportunities based on US Department of Labor statistics. Importantly, the booklet highlights the successful careers of FAU geoscience recent alumni. The booklet is useful for students to guide their career planning. 

3. Geoscience Promotional Videos. The teams have created a two-minute geoscience program promotional video, to publicize Geosciences Department programs at FAU and geoscience in general. It has been put on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvUpwsh26xU), the FAU Geoscience department website (geosciences.fau.edu), FAU College of Science social media. A shorter version (45 seconds) was edited from the long version for recruiting campaigns through Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/72083467621/posts/10159191411842622) and  Instagram.  They are also used to recruit students for the summer programs and at various other outreach events.

4. Exploring GEOPAths Summer Institute (EGSI).  An EGSI was developed to use  high-impact practices for inspiring students about pursuing academic studies and careers in geoscience, including high-tech applications in the field, field-work experiences, career path awareness, and hands-on research exposure with integrated social interactions between professionals, peers and faculty. To adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic and in response to student feedback, 4 versions of EGSIs were planned and implemented in the past 4 years, 3-day, 8-day, 7-day, and 1-day. The last 1-day camp was for FAU students only, while the others were for PBSC students. While the longer camps are more comprehensive and impactful, the shorter options are more flexible and more sustainable. After each of the first three summer programs for PBSC students, at least one attendee joined our program.

5. Undergraduate GEOPAths Research Experiences (UGRE).  A UGRE was implemented to retain geoscience majors to continue pursuing further studies and a future career in the geosciences. In UGRE, students were immersed in in-depth field-work and authentic research experiential activities: environmental geophysics study in wetland environment in Maine or investigating coastal morphological changes with field survey supported by drones at SE Florida coast. All the students who participated in the UGRE either have graduated with a geoscience degree or are still pursuing geoscience degrees.

6. Department Webpage Update and Alumni Highlights. With the support from the FAU College of Science communications team, the department webpages have been updated with the promotional videos, alumni highlights, field camp photos, and transfer information. We also collected testimonials from a dozen recent alumni and used these to better inform potential students about the exciting opportunities in geoscience (http://www.geosciences.fau.edu/news/student-highlights/index.php).

7. Canvas Course Shell. A canvas module was developed and embedded in several general education and high enrollment courses at PBSC and FAU.  The module is used to raise awareness of  geoscience as a rigorous science discipline and a rewarding career path, promote FAU geosciences degree programs and workforce readiness (link to alumni testimonials),  advertise EGSI opportunities to PBSC students,  and provide details of the corresponding PBSC-to-FAU 2+2 transfer flight-plans, and application process for PBSC transfer students and for FAU student who would like to change majors.

8. FAU Program Enrollment, Demographic Shifts and PBSC Transfer.   

The teams examined the 6-year trend of FAU Geosciences undergraduate major enrollment before and during the GEOPAths project period (2018-2023), which coincidently covers COVID-19 pandemic period.  It shows that FAU Geosciences major enrollment has been positively impacted by the GEOPAths activities. In comparison with almost all other science majors at FAU, especially the smaller ones, Geosciences enrollment had a strong resilience at the start of the pandemic, rebounded nicely after, and now surpasses the base year (2018) enrollment before the pandemic while most others are still under.

With regards to student demographic, we found that the overall minority percentage of FAU Geoscience majors has significantly increased in the past 6 years, so are the percentage of two selected groups: Hispanic or Latino, and Black or African American. However, these are still much lower than the college average.

We also compared the number of PBSC students transferred to FAU before and during the GEOPAths project. The data show that overall, the number of PBSC transfer students has significantly increased in comparison with the base year, although it fluctuates over years as expected.


Last Modified: 08/27/2024
Modified by: Zhixiao Xie

por.por_txt_cntn:
The GEOPAths teams at Florida Atlantic University(FAU) (4-year) and Palm Beach State College (PBSC) (2-year) worked collaboratively to grow student awareness of geoscience as a rigorous STEM discipline with a rewarding career path, and to increase the recruitment and retention of students in FAU geoscience degree programs. The outcomes from this project include:


1. FAU-PBSC Transfer Articulation Agreement. The teams have established a geoscience specific agreement and related flight plans, which facilitates a transfer pathway for PBSC Associate of Arts (AA, 2-year) students to undergraduate degree programs leading to a B.A or B.S. in Geosciences at FAU. More information can be found at: https://www.palmbeachstate.edu/transfer/as-degree-transfer-agreements.aspx


2.FAU Geoscience Career Booklet.A geoscience career booklet has been compiled to showcase exciting geoscience careers and promote career readiness to potential students. It is a 10-page document that details the rewarding career opportunities based on US Department of Labor statistics. Importantly, the booklet highlights the successful careers of FAU geoscience recent alumni. The booklet is useful for students to guide their career planning.


3. Geoscience Promotional Videos.The teams have created a two-minute geoscience program promotional video, to publicize Geosciences Department programs at FAU and geoscience in general. It has been put on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvUpwsh26xU), the FAU Geoscience department website (geosciences.fau.edu), FAU College of Science social media. A shorter version (45 seconds) was edited from the long version for recruiting campaigns through Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/72083467621/posts/10159191411842622) and Instagram. They are also used to recruit students for the summer programs and at various other outreach events.


4. Exploring GEOPAths Summer Institute (EGSI). An EGSI was developed to use high-impact practices for inspiring students about pursuing academic studies and careers in geoscience, including high-tech applications in the field, field-work experiences, career path awareness, and hands-on research exposure with integrated social interactions between professionals, peers and faculty. To adapt to the COVID-19 pandemic and in response to student feedback, 4 versions of EGSIs were planned and implemented in the past 4 years, 3-day, 8-day, 7-day, and 1-day. The last 1-day camp was for FAU students only, while the others were for PBSC students. While the longer camps are more comprehensive and impactful, the shorter options are more flexible and more sustainable. After each of the first three summer programs for PBSC students, at least one attendee joined our program.


5. Undergraduate GEOPAths Research Experiences (UGRE).A UGRE was implemented to retain geoscience majors to continue pursuing further studies and a future career in the geosciences. All the students who participated in the UGRE either have graduated with a geoscience degree or are still pursuing geoscience degrees.


6.Department Webpage Update and Alumni Highlights.With the support from the FAU College of Science communications team, the department webpages have been updated with the promotional videos, alumni highlights, field camp photos, and transfer information. We also collected testimonials from a dozen recent alumni and used these to better inform potential students about the exciting opportunities in geoscience (http://www.geosciences.fau.edu/news/student-highlights/index.php).


7. Canvas Course Shell.A canvas module was developed and embedded in several general education and high enrollment courses at PBSC and FAU. The module is used to raise awareness of geoscience as a rigorous science discipline and a rewarding career path, promote FAU geosciences degree programs and workforce readiness (link to alumni testimonials), advertise EGSI opportunities to PBSC students, and provide details of the corresponding PBSC-to-FAU 2+2 transfer flight-plans, and application process for PBSC transfer students and for FAU student who would like to change majors.


8. FAU Program Enrollment, Demographic Shifts and PBSC Transfer. 


The teams examined the 6-year trend of FAU Geosciences undergraduate major enrollment before and during the GEOPAths project period (2018-2023), which coincidently covers COVID-19 pandemic period. It shows that FAU Geosciences major enrollment has been positively impacted by the GEOPAths activities. In comparison with almost all other science majors at FAU, especially the smaller ones, Geosciences enrollment had a strong resilience at the start of the pandemic, rebounded nicely after, and now surpasses the base year (2018) enrollment before the pandemic while most others are still under.


With regards to student demographic, we found that the overall minority percentage of FAU Geoscience majors has significantly increased in the past 6 years, so are the percentage of two selected groups: Hispanic or Latino, and Black or African American. However, these are still much lower than the college average.


We also compared the number of PBSC students transferred to FAU before and during the GEOPAths project. The data show that overall, the number of PBSC transfer students has significantly increased in comparison with the base year, although it fluctuates over years as expected.
